trans-unit.source: Azure Multi-Factor Authentication - What's Next
trans-unit.target: Azure Multi-Factor Authentication - What's Next

trans-unit.source: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that describes what to do next with MFA.
trans-unit.target: This is the Azure Multi-factor authentication page that describes what to do next with MFA.

trans-unit.source: This includes reports, fraud alert, one-time bypass, custom voice messages, caching, trusted ips and app passwords.
trans-unit.target: This includes reports, fraud alert, one-time bypass, custom voice messages, caching, trusted ips and app passwords.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: Configuring Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: The following article will help you manage Azure Multi-Factor Authentication now that you are up and running.
trans-unit.target: The following article will help you manage Azure Multi-Factor Authentication now that you are up and running.

trans-unit.source: It covers a variety of topics that will allow you to get the most out of Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: It covers a variety of topics that will allow you to get the most out of Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Please be aware that not all of these features are available in every version of Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Please be aware that not all of these features are available in every version of Azure Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: Feature
trans-unit.target: Feature

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: What is covered
trans-unit.target: What is covered

trans-unit.source: Fraud alert
trans-unit.target: Fraud alert

trans-unit.source: Fraud alert can be configured and setup so that your users can report fraudulent attempts to access their resources.
trans-unit.target: Fraud alert can be configured and setup so that your users can report fraudulent attempts to access their resources.

trans-unit.source: How to setup, configure and report fraud
trans-unit.target: How to setup, configure and report fraud

trans-unit.source: One-time bypass
trans-unit.target: One-time bypass

trans-unit.source: A one-time bypass allows a user to authenticate a single time by "bypassing" multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: A one-time bypass allows a user to authenticate a single time by "bypassing" multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: How to setup and configure a one-time bypass
trans-unit.target: How to setup and configure a one-time bypass

trans-unit.source: Custom Voice Messages
trans-unit.target: Custom Voice Messages

trans-unit.source: Custom voice messages allow you to use your own recordings or greetings with multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Custom voice messages allow you to use your own recordings or greetings with multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: How to setup and configure custom greetings and messages
trans-unit.target: How to setup and configure custom greetings and messages

trans-unit.source: Caching
trans-unit.target: Caching

trans-unit.source: Caching allows you to set a specific time period so that subsequent authentication attempts succeed automatically.
trans-unit.target: Caching allows you to set a specific time period so that subsequent authentication attempts succeed automatically.

trans-unit.source: How to setup and configure authentication caching.
trans-unit.target: How to setup and configure authentication caching.

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs is a feature of multi-factor authentication that allows administrators of a managed or federated tenant the ability to bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s local intranet.
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs is a feature of multi-factor authentication that allows administrators of a managed or federated tenant the ability to bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s local intranet.

trans-unit.source: Configure and setup IP addresses that are exempt for multi-factor authentication
trans-unit.target: Configure and setup IP addresses that are exempt for multi-factor authentication

trans-unit.source: App Passwords
trans-unit.target: App Passwords

trans-unit.source: App passwords allows an application that is not mfa aware to bypass multi-factor authentication and continue working.
trans-unit.target: App passwords allows an application that is not mfa aware to bypass multi-factor authentication and continue working.

trans-unit.source: Information about app passwords.
trans-unit.target: Information about app passwords.

trans-unit.source: Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers (Public Preview)
trans-unit.target: Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers (Public Preview)

trans-unit.source: Allows you to suspend MFA for a set number of days after a user has successfully signed in using MFA.
trans-unit.target: Allows you to suspend MFA for a set number of days after a user has successfully signed in using MFA.

trans-unit.source: Information about enabling this feature and setting up the number of days.
trans-unit.target: Information about enabling this feature and setting up the number of days.

trans-unit.source: Fraud Alert
trans-unit.target: Fraud Alert

trans-unit.source: Fraud alert can be configured and setup so that your users can report fraudulent attempts to access their resources.
trans-unit.target: Fraud alert can be configured and setup so that your users can report fraudulent attempts to access their resources.

trans-unit.source: Users can report fraud either with the mobile app or through their phone.
trans-unit.target: Users can report fraud either with the mobile app or through their phone.

trans-unit.source: To setup and configure fraud alert
trans-unit.target: To setup and configure fraud alert

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to enable fraud alerting on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to enable fraud alerting on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Settings.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Settings.

trans-unit.source: Under the Fraud Alert section, place a check in Allow users to submit Fraud Alerts.
trans-unit.target: Under the Fraud Alert section, place a check in Allow users to submit Fraud Alerts.

trans-unit.source: If you want users to be blocked when fraud is reported, place a check in Block user when fraud is reported.
trans-unit.target: If you want users to be blocked when fraud is reported, place a check in Block user when fraud is reported.

trans-unit.source: In the box under Code To Report Fraud During Initial Greeting enter a number code that can be used during call verification.
trans-unit.target: In the box under Code To Report Fraud During Initial Greeting enter a number code that can be used during call verification.

trans-unit.source: If a user enters this code, instead of the # sign, then a fraud alert will be reported.
trans-unit.target: If a user enters this code, instead of the # sign, then a fraud alert will be reported.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom, click Save.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom, click Save.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: To report fraud alert
trans-unit.target: To report fraud alert

trans-unit.source: Fraud alert can be reported two ways.
trans-unit.target: Fraud alert can be reported two ways.

trans-unit.source: Either through the mobile app or through the phone.
trans-unit.target: Either through the mobile app or through the phone.

trans-unit.source: To report fraud alert with the mobile app
trans-unit.target: To report fraud alert with the mobile app

trans-unit.source: When a verification is sent to your phone click on it and it will start the Multi-Factor Authentication app.
trans-unit.target: When a verification is sent to your phone click on it and it will start the Multi-Factor Authentication app.

trans-unit.source: To report fraud, click the Cancel and Report Fraud.
trans-unit.target: To report fraud, click the Cancel and Report Fraud.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a box that says your organizations IT
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a box that says your organizations IT

trans-unit.source: Support staff will be notified.
trans-unit.target: Support staff will be notified.

trans-unit.source: Click report fraud.
trans-unit.target: Click report fraud.

trans-unit.source: On the app, click Close.
trans-unit.target: On the app, click Close.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: To report fraud alert with the phone
trans-unit.target: To report fraud alert with the phone

trans-unit.source: When a verification call comes in to your phone answer it.
trans-unit.target: When a verification call comes in to your phone answer it.

trans-unit.source: To report fraud, enter the code that has been configured to correspond with reporting fraud via the phone and then the # sign.
trans-unit.target: To report fraud, enter the code that has been configured to correspond with reporting fraud via the phone and then the # sign.

trans-unit.source: You will be notified that a fraud alert has been submitted.
trans-unit.target: You will be notified that a fraud alert has been submitted.

trans-unit.source: End the call.
trans-unit.target: End the call.

trans-unit.source: To view the fraud report
trans-unit.target: To view the fraud report

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to view the fraud alert report and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to view the fraud alert report and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under View A Report, click Fraud Alert.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under View A Report, click Fraud Alert.

trans-unit.source: Specify the date range that you wish to view in the report.
trans-unit.target: Specify the date range that you wish to view in the report.

trans-unit.source: Also you can specify any specific usernames, phone numbers and the users status.
trans-unit.target: Also you can specify any specific usernames, phone numbers and the users status.

trans-unit.source: Click Run.
trans-unit.target: Click Run.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a report similar to the one below.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a report similar to the one below.

trans-unit.source: You can also click Export to CSV if you wish to export the report.
trans-unit.target: You can also click Export to CSV if you wish to export the report.

trans-unit.source: One-time bypass
trans-unit.target: One-time bypass

trans-unit.source: A one-time bypass allows a user to authenticate a single time by "bypassing" multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: A one-time bypass allows a user to authenticate a single time by "bypassing" multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: The bypass is temporary and expires after the specified number of seconds.
trans-unit.target: The bypass is temporary and expires after the specified number of seconds.

trans-unit.source: So in situations where the mobile app or phone is not receiving a notification or phone-call, you can enable a one-time bypass so the user can access the desired resource.
trans-unit.target: So in situations where the mobile app or phone is not receiving a notification or phone-call, you can enable a one-time bypass so the user can access the desired resource.

trans-unit.source: To create a one-time bypass
trans-unit.target: To create a one-time bypass

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one that is associated with the directory for the user you wish to create a one-time bypass for and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one that is associated with the directory for the user you wish to create a one-time bypass for and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under User Administration, click Settings.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under User Administration, click Settings.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: On the One-Time Bypass page, click New One-Time Bypass.
trans-unit.target: On the One-Time Bypass page, click New One-Time Bypass.

trans-unit.source: Enter the user’s username, the number of seconds that the bypass will exist, the reason for the bypass and click Bypass.
trans-unit.target: Enter the user’s username, the number of seconds that the bypass will exist, the reason for the bypass and click Bypass.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: At this point, the user must sign in before the one-time bypass expires.
trans-unit.target: At this point, the user must sign in before the one-time bypass expires.

trans-unit.source: To view the one-time bypass report
trans-unit.target: To view the one-time bypass report

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to view the fraud alert report and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to view the fraud alert report and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under View A Report, click One-Time Bypass.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, under View A Report, click One-Time Bypass.

trans-unit.source: Specify the date range that you wish to view in the report.
trans-unit.target: Specify the date range that you wish to view in the report.

trans-unit.source: Also you can specify any specific usernames, phone numbers and the users status.
trans-unit.target: Also you can specify any specific usernames, phone numbers and the users status.

trans-unit.source: Click Run.
trans-unit.target: Click Run.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a report similar to the one below.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a report similar to the one below.

trans-unit.source: You can also click Export to CSV if you wish to export the report.
trans-unit.target: You can also click Export to CSV if you wish to export the report.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Custom voice messages
trans-unit.target: Custom voice messages

trans-unit.source: Custom voice messages allow you to use your own recordings or greetings with multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Custom voice messages allow you to use your own recordings or greetings with multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: These can be used in addition to or to replace the Microsoft records.
trans-unit.target: These can be used in addition to or to replace the Microsoft records.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin be aware of the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin be aware of the following:

trans-unit.source: The current supported file formats are .wav and .mp3.
trans-unit.target: The current supported file formats are .wav and .mp3.

trans-unit.source: The file size limit is 5MB.
trans-unit.target: The file size limit is 5MB.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended that for Authentication messages that it be no longer than 20 seconds.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended that for Authentication messages that it be no longer than 20 seconds.

trans-unit.source: Anything greater than this could cause the verification to fail because the user may not respond before the message finishes and the verification times out.
trans-unit.target: Anything greater than this could cause the verification to fail because the user may not respond before the message finishes and the verification times out.

trans-unit.source: To setup custom voice messages in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: To setup custom voice messages in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: Create a custom voice message using one of the supported file formats.
trans-unit.target: Create a custom voice message using one of the supported file formats.

trans-unit.source: See Custom Voice Message Recommendations below.
trans-unit.target: See Custom Voice Message Recommendations below.

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to configure the custom voice message on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to configure the custom voice message on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Voice Messages.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Voice Messages.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Under the Voice Messages section, click New Voice Message.
trans-unit.target: Under the Voice Messages section, click New Voice Message.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: On the Configure: New Voice Messages page, click Manage Sound Files.
trans-unit.target: On the Configure: New Voice Messages page, click Manage Sound Files.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: On the Configure: Sound Files page, click Upload Sound File.
trans-unit.target: On the Configure: Sound Files page, click Upload Sound File.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: On the Configure: Upload Sound File, click Browse and navigate to your voice message, click Open.
trans-unit.target: On the Configure: Upload Sound File, click Browse and navigate to your voice message, click Open.

trans-unit.source: Add a Description and click Upload.
trans-unit.target: Add a Description and click Upload.

trans-unit.source: Once this completes, you will see a message that you have successfully uploaded the file.
trans-unit.target: Once this completes, you will see a message that you have successfully uploaded the file.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click Voice Messages.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click Voice Messages.

trans-unit.source: Under the Voice Messages section, click New Voice Message.
trans-unit.target: Under the Voice Messages section, click New Voice Message.

trans-unit.source: From the Language drop-down, select a language.
trans-unit.target: From the Language drop-down, select a language.

trans-unit.source: If this message is for a specific application, specify it in the Application box.
trans-unit.target: If this message is for a specific application, specify it in the Application box.

trans-unit.source: From the Message Type, select the message type that will be overridden with our new custom message.
trans-unit.target: From the Message Type, select the message type that will be overridden with our new custom message.

trans-unit.source: From the Sound File drop-down, select your sound file.
trans-unit.target: From the Sound File drop-down, select your sound file.

trans-unit.source: Click Create.
trans-unit.target: Click Create.

trans-unit.source: You will see a message that says you have successfully created a voice message.
trans-unit.target: You will see a message that says you have successfully created a voice message.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Caching in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: Caching in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: Caching allows you to set a specific time period so that subsequent authentication attempts succeed automatically.
trans-unit.target: Caching allows you to set a specific time period so that subsequent authentication attempts succeed automatically.

trans-unit.source: This allows your users to avoid having to wait for phone calls or text if they authenticate within this time period.
trans-unit.target: This allows your users to avoid having to wait for phone calls or text if they authenticate within this time period.

trans-unit.source: To setup caching in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: To setup caching in Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Log on to [http://azure.microsoft.com](http://azure.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: At the top select Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.
trans-unit.target: This will bring up a list of your Multi-Factor Auth Providers.

trans-unit.source: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to enable fraud alerting on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: If you have more than one Multi-Factor Auth Provider, select the one you wish to enable fraud alerting on and click Manage at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: If you have only one, just click Manage.
trans-unit.target: If you have only one, just click Manage.

trans-unit.source: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: This will open the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Caching.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Multi-Factor Authentication Management Portal, on the left, click Caching.

trans-unit.source: On the Configure caching page click New Cache
trans-unit.target: On the Configure caching page click New Cache

trans-unit.source: Select the Cache type and the cache seconds.
trans-unit.target: Select the Cache type and the cache seconds.

trans-unit.source: Click create.
trans-unit.target: Click create.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs

trans-unit.source: Trusted IPs is a feature of multi-factor authentication that allows administrators of a managed or federated tenant the ability to bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s local intranet.
trans-unit.target: Trusted IPs is a feature of multi-factor authentication that allows administrators of a managed or federated tenant the ability to bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s local intranet.

trans-unit.source: The features are available for Azure AD tenants that have Azure AD Premium, Enterprise Mobility Suite or Azure Multi-Factor Authentication licenses.
trans-unit.target: The features are available for Azure AD tenants that have Azure AD Premium, Enterprise Mobility Suite or Azure Multi-Factor Authentication licenses.

trans-unit.source: Type of Azure AD Tenant
trans-unit.target: Type of Azure AD Tenant

trans-unit.source: Available Trusted IP options
trans-unit.target: Available Trusted IP options

trans-unit.source: Managed
trans-unit.target: Managed

trans-unit.source: Specific IP address ranges – Administrators can specify a range of IP addresses that can bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s intranet..
trans-unit.target: Specific IP address ranges – Administrators can specify a range of IP addresses that can bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s intranet..

trans-unit.source: Federated
trans-unit.target: Federated

trans-unit.source: All Federated Users - All federated users who are signing-in from inside the organization will bypass multi-factor authentication using a claim issued by AD FS.
trans-unit.target: All Federated Users - All federated users who are signing-in from inside the organization will bypass multi-factor authentication using a claim issued by AD FS.

trans-unit.source: Specific IP address ranges – Administrators can specify a range of IP addresses that can bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s intranet.
trans-unit.target: Specific IP address ranges – Administrators can specify a range of IP addresses that can bypass multi-factor authentication for users that are signing in from the company’s intranet.

trans-unit.source: This bypass only works from inside a company’s intranet.
trans-unit.target: This bypass only works from inside a company’s intranet.

trans-unit.source: So for example, if you only selected all federated users, and a user signs in from outside the company’s intranet, that user will have to authenticate using multi-factor authentication even if the user presents an AD FS claim.
trans-unit.target: So for example, if you only selected all federated users, and a user signs in from outside the company’s intranet, that user will have to authenticate using multi-factor authentication even if the user presents an AD FS claim.

trans-unit.source: The following table describes when multi-factor authentication and app passwords are required inside your corpnet and outside your corpnet when Trusted IPs is enabled.
trans-unit.target: The following table describes when multi-factor authentication and app passwords are required inside your corpnet and outside your corpnet when Trusted IPs is enabled.

trans-unit.source: |Trusted IPs enabled| Trusted IPs disabled
trans-unit.target: |Trusted IPs enabled| Trusted IPs disabled

trans-unit.source: Inside corpnet|For browser flows multi-factor authentication NOT required.|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required
trans-unit.target: Inside corpnet|For browser flows multi-factor authentication NOT required.|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required

trans-unit.source: |For rich client apps, regular passwords will work if the user has not created any app passwords.
trans-unit.target: |For rich client apps, regular passwords will work if the user has not created any app passwords.

trans-unit.source: Once an app password has been created, app passwords are required.|For rich client apps, app passwords required
trans-unit.target: Once an app password has been created, app passwords are required.|For rich client apps, app passwords required

trans-unit.source: Outside corpnet|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required.|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required.
trans-unit.target: Outside corpnet|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required.|For browser flows, multi-factor authentication required.

trans-unit.source: |For rich client apps, app passwords required.|For rich client apps, app passwords required.
trans-unit.target: |For rich client apps, app passwords required.|For rich client apps, app passwords required.

trans-unit.source: To enable Trusted IPs
trans-unit.target: To enable Trusted IPs

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Under, Directory click on the directory you wish to setup Trusted IPsing on.
trans-unit.target: Under, Directory click on the directory you wish to setup Trusted IPsing on.

trans-unit.source: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.
trans-unit.target: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.

trans-unit.source: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.
trans-unit.target: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.

trans-unit.source: On the Service Settings page, under Trusted IPs, select either:
trans-unit.target: On the Service Settings page, under Trusted IPs, select either:

trans-unit.source: For requests from federated users originating from my intranet – All federated users who are signing in from the corporate network will bypass multi-factor authentication using a claim issued by AD FS.
trans-unit.target: For requests from federated users originating from my intranet – All federated users who are signing in from the corporate network will bypass multi-factor authentication using a claim issued by AD FS.

trans-unit.source: For requests from a specific range of public IPs – enter the IP addresses in the boxes provided using CIDR notation.
trans-unit.target: For requests from a specific range of public IPs – enter the IP addresses in the boxes provided using CIDR notation.

trans-unit.source: For example: xxx.xxx.xxx.0/24 for IP addresses in the range xxx.xxx.xxx.1 – xxx.xxx.xxx.254, or xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx/32 for a single IP address.
trans-unit.target: For example: xxx.xxx.xxx.0/24 for IP addresses in the range xxx.xxx.xxx.1 – xxx.xxx.xxx.254, or xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx/32 for a single IP address.

trans-unit.source: You can enter up to 12 IP address ranges.
trans-unit.target: You can enter up to 12 IP address ranges.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Click save.
trans-unit.target: Click save.

trans-unit.source: Once the updates have been applied, click close.
trans-unit.target: Once the updates have been applied, click close.

trans-unit.source: App Passwords
trans-unit.target: App Passwords

trans-unit.source: In some apps, like Office 2010 or older and Apple Mail you can't use multi-factor authenticaton.
trans-unit.target: In some apps, like Office 2010 or older and Apple Mail you can't use multi-factor authenticaton.

trans-unit.source: To use these apps, you'll need to use "app passwords" in place of your traditional password.
trans-unit.target: To use these apps, you'll need to use "app passwords" in place of your traditional password.

trans-unit.source: The app password allows the application to bypass multi-factor authentication and continue working.
trans-unit.target: The app password allows the application to bypass multi-factor authentication and continue working.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] Modern Authentication for the Office 2013 Clients
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] Modern Authentication for the Office 2013 Clients

trans-unit.source: Office 2013 clients (including Outlook) now support new Authentication Protocols and can be enabled to support Multi-Factor Authentication.
trans-unit.target: Office 2013 clients (including Outlook) now support new Authentication Protocols and can be enabled to support Multi-Factor Authentication.

trans-unit.source: This means that once enabled, app passwords are not required for use with Office 2013 clients.
trans-unit.target: This means that once enabled, app passwords are not required for use with Office 2013 clients.

trans-unit.source: For more information see [Office 2013 modern authentication public preview announced](https://blogs.office.com/2015/03/23/office-2013-modern-authentication-public-preview-announced/).
trans-unit.target: For more information see [Office 2013 modern authentication public preview announced](https://blogs.office.com/2015/03/23/office-2013-modern-authentication-public-preview-announced/).

trans-unit.source: Important things to know about app passwords
trans-unit.target: Important things to know about app passwords

trans-unit.source: The following is an important list of things that you should know about app passwords.
trans-unit.target: The following is an important list of things that you should know about app passwords.

trans-unit.source: Authentication Experience
trans-unit.target: Authentication Experience

trans-unit.source: For browser based apps
trans-unit.target: For browser based apps

trans-unit.source: For non-browser based apps
trans-unit.target: For non-browser based apps

trans-unit.source: The 1st factor of authentication is performed on-premises
trans-unit.target: The 1st factor of authentication is performed on-premises

trans-unit.source: The 2nd factor is a phone based method carried out by Cloud Identity.
trans-unit.target: The 2nd factor is a phone based method carried out by Cloud Identity.

trans-unit.source: Admins and users can use app passwords to sign-in.
trans-unit.target: Admins and users can use app passwords to sign-in.

trans-unit.source: Users can have multiple app passwords which increases the surface area for theft.
trans-unit.target: Users can have multiple app passwords which increases the surface area for theft.

trans-unit.source: Since app passwords are hard to remember, it might encourage people to write this down.
trans-unit.target: Since app passwords are hard to remember, it might encourage people to write this down.

trans-unit.source: This is not recommended and should be discouraged because only one factor is required to login with app password.
trans-unit.target: This is not recommended and should be discouraged because only one factor is required to login with app password.

trans-unit.source: Apps which cache passwords and use it in on-premise scenarios might start failing since the app password will not be known outside of the organizational id.
trans-unit.target: Apps which cache passwords and use it in on-premise scenarios might start failing since the app password will not be known outside of the organizational id.

trans-unit.source: An example is Exchange emails that are on-premise but the archived mail is in the cloud.
trans-unit.target: An example is Exchange emails that are on-premise but the archived mail is in the cloud.

trans-unit.source: The same password will not work.
trans-unit.target: The same password will not work.

trans-unit.source: The actual password is automatically generated and is not supplied by the user.
trans-unit.target: The actual password is automatically generated and is not supplied by the user.

trans-unit.source: This is because the automatically generated password, is harder for an attacker to guess and is more secure.
trans-unit.target: This is because the automatically generated password, is harder for an attacker to guess and is more secure.

trans-unit.source: Currently there is a limit of 40 passwords per user.
trans-unit.target: Currently there is a limit of 40 passwords per user.

trans-unit.source: You will be prompted to delete told to delete one of your existing app passwords in order to create a new one.
trans-unit.target: You will be prompted to delete told to delete one of your existing app passwords in order to create a new one.

trans-unit.source: Once multi-factor authentication is enabled on a user's account, app passwords can be used with most non-browser clients such as Outlook and Lync, but administrative actions cannot be performed using app passwords through non-browser applications such as Windows PowerShell even if that user has an administrative account.
trans-unit.target: Once multi-factor authentication is enabled on a user's account, app passwords can be used with most non-browser clients such as Outlook and Lync, but administrative actions cannot be performed using app passwords through non-browser applications such as Windows PowerShell even if that user has an administrative account.

trans-unit.source: Ensure you create a service account with a strong password to run PowerShell scripts and do not enable that account for multi-factor authentication.
trans-unit.target: Ensure you create a service account with a strong password to run PowerShell scripts and do not enable that account for multi-factor authentication.

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.WARNING] App passwords will not work in hybrid environments where clients communicate with both on-premises and cloud autodiscover endpoints.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.WARNING] App passwords will not work in hybrid environments where clients communicate with both on-premises and cloud autodiscover endpoints.

trans-unit.source: Please be aware that app passwords will not work in hybrid environments where clients communicate with both on-premises and cloud autodiscover endpoints since domain passwords are required to authenticate on-premises and app passwords are required to authenticate with the cloud.
trans-unit.target: Please be aware that app passwords will not work in hybrid environments where clients communicate with both on-premises and cloud autodiscover endpoints since domain passwords are required to authenticate on-premises and app passwords are required to authenticate with the cloud.

trans-unit.source: Naming Guidance for App Passwords
trans-unit.target: Naming Guidance for App Passwords

trans-unit.source: It is recommended that app password names should reflect the device on which they will be used.
trans-unit.target: It is recommended that app password names should reflect the device on which they will be used.

trans-unit.source: For instance, if you have a laptop that has non-browser apps such as Outlook, Word, and Excel, you only need to create one app password named Laptop and use that app password in all of these applications.
trans-unit.target: For instance, if you have a laptop that has non-browser apps such as Outlook, Word, and Excel, you only need to create one app password named Laptop and use that app password in all of these applications.

trans-unit.source: Although you can create separate passwords for all of these applications, it is not recommended.
trans-unit.target: Although you can create separate passwords for all of these applications, it is not recommended.

trans-unit.source: The recommend way is to use one app password per device.
trans-unit.target: The recommend way is to use one app password per device.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Federated (SSO) App Passwords
trans-unit.target: Federated (SSO) App Passwords

trans-unit.source: Azure AD supports federation with on-premises Windows Server Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).
trans-unit.target: Azure AD supports federation with on-premises Windows Server Active Directory Domain Services (AD DS).

trans-unit.source: If your organization is federated(SSO) with Azure AD and you are going to be using Azure Multi-Factor Authentication, then the following is important information that you should be aware when using app passwords.
trans-unit.target: If your organization is federated(SSO) with Azure AD and you are going to be using Azure Multi-Factor Authentication, then the following is important information that you should be aware when using app passwords.

trans-unit.source: This applies only to federated(SSO) customers.
trans-unit.target: This applies only to federated(SSO) customers.

trans-unit.source: The App Password is verified by Azure AD and hence bypasses federation.
trans-unit.target: The App Password is verified by Azure AD and hence bypasses federation.

trans-unit.source: Federation is only actively used when setting up App Password.
trans-unit.target: Federation is only actively used when setting up App Password.

trans-unit.source: For federated(SSO) users, we will never go to the Identity Provider (IdP) unlike the passive flow.
trans-unit.target: For federated(SSO) users, we will never go to the Identity Provider (IdP) unlike the passive flow.

trans-unit.source: The passwords will be stored in the organizational id.
trans-unit.target: The passwords will be stored in the organizational id.

trans-unit.source: If the user leaves the company, that info has to flow to organizational id using DirSync in real time.
trans-unit.target: If the user leaves the company, that info has to flow to organizational id using DirSync in real time.

trans-unit.source: Account disable/deletion may take up to 3 hours to sync, delaying disable/deletion of App Password in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Account disable/deletion may take up to 3 hours to sync, delaying disable/deletion of App Password in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: On-premises Client Access Control settings are not honored by App Password
trans-unit.target: On-premises Client Access Control settings are not honored by App Password

trans-unit.source: No on-premises authentication logging / auditing capability is available for App Password
trans-unit.target: No on-premises authentication logging / auditing capability is available for App Password

trans-unit.source: More end-user education is required for the Microsoft Lync 2013 client.
trans-unit.target: More end-user education is required for the Microsoft Lync 2013 client.

trans-unit.source: For the required steps, see How to change the password in your email to the app password.
trans-unit.target: For the required steps, see How to change the password in your email to the app password.

trans-unit.source: Certain advanced architectural designs may require using a combination of organizational username and passwords and app passwords when using multi-factor authentication with clients, depending on where they authenticate.
trans-unit.target: Certain advanced architectural designs may require using a combination of organizational username and passwords and app passwords when using multi-factor authentication with clients, depending on where they authenticate.

trans-unit.source: For clients that authenticate against an on-premise infrastructure, you would use an organizational username and password.
trans-unit.target: For clients that authenticate against an on-premise infrastructure, you would use an organizational username and password.

trans-unit.source: For clients that authenticate against Azure AD, you would use the app password.
trans-unit.target: For clients that authenticate against Azure AD, you would use the app password.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you have an architecture that consists of the following:
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you have an architecture that consists of the following:

trans-unit.source: You are federating your on-premise instance of Active Directory with Azure AD
trans-unit.target: You are federating your on-premise instance of Active Directory with Azure AD

trans-unit.source: You are using Exchange online
trans-unit.target: You are using Exchange online

trans-unit.source: You are using Lync that is specifically on-premise
trans-unit.target: You are using Lync that is specifically on-premise

trans-unit.source: You are using Azure Multi-Factor Authentication
trans-unit.target: You are using Azure Multi-Factor Authentication

trans-unit.source: Proofup
trans-unit.target: Proofup

trans-unit.source: In these instances, you must do the following:
trans-unit.target: In these instances, you must do the following:

trans-unit.source: When signing-in to Lync, use your organizations’ username and password.
trans-unit.target: When signing-in to Lync, use your organizations’ username and password.

trans-unit.source: When attempting to access the address book via an Outlook client that connects to Exchange online, use an app password.
trans-unit.target: When attempting to access the address book via an Outlook client that connects to Exchange online, use an app password.

trans-unit.source: Allowing app password creation
trans-unit.target: Allowing app password creation

trans-unit.source: By default, users cannot create app passwords.
trans-unit.target: By default, users cannot create app passwords.

trans-unit.source: This feature must be enabled.
trans-unit.target: This feature must be enabled.

trans-unit.source: To allow users the ability to create app passwords use the following procedure.
trans-unit.target: To allow users the ability to create app passwords use the following procedure.

trans-unit.source: To enable users to create app passwords
trans-unit.target: To enable users to create app passwords

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Under, Directory click on the directory for the user you wish to enable.
trans-unit.target: Under, Directory click on the directory for the user you wish to enable.

trans-unit.source: At the top, click Users.
trans-unit.target: At the top, click Users.

trans-unit.source: At the bottom of the page, click Manage Multi-Factor Auth.
trans-unit.target: At the bottom of the page, click Manage Multi-Factor Auth.

trans-unit.source: This will open the multi-factor authentication page.
trans-unit.target: This will open the multi-factor authentication page.

trans-unit.source: At the top of the multi-factor authentication page, click Service Settings.
trans-unit.target: At the top of the multi-factor authentication page, click Service Settings.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that the radio button next to Allow users to create app passwords to sign into non-browser applications is selected.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that the radio button next to Allow users to create app passwords to sign into non-browser applications is selected.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Creating app passwords
trans-unit.target: Creating app passwords

trans-unit.source: Users can create app passwords during their initial registration.
trans-unit.target: Users can create app passwords during their initial registration.

trans-unit.source: They are given an option at the end of the registration process that allows them to create them.
trans-unit.target: They are given an option at the end of the registration process that allows them to create them.

trans-unit.source: Additionally users can also create app passwords later on by changing their settings in the Azure Portal, the Office 365 portal or by
trans-unit.target: Additionally users can also create app passwords later on by changing their settings in the Azure Portal, the Office 365 portal or by

trans-unit.source: To create app passwords in the Office 365 portal
trans-unit.target: To create app passwords in the Office 365 portal

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Office 365 portal
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Office 365 portal

trans-unit.source: In the top right corner select the settings widget
trans-unit.target: In the top right corner select the settings widget

trans-unit.source: On the left, select Additional Security Verification
trans-unit.target: On the left, select Additional Security Verification

trans-unit.source: On the right, select **Update my phone numbers used for account security**
trans-unit.target: On the right, select **Update my phone numbers used for account security**

trans-unit.source: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords
trans-unit.target: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**

trans-unit.source: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.
trans-unit.target: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: To create app passwords in the Azure portal
trans-unit.target: To create app passwords in the Azure portal

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Azure Management portal
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Azure Management portal

trans-unit.source: At the top, right-click on your user name and select Additional Security Verification.
trans-unit.target: At the top, right-click on your user name and select Additional Security Verification.

trans-unit.source: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords
trans-unit.target: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**

trans-unit.source: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.
trans-unit.target: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: To create app passwords if you do not have an Office 365 or Azure subscription
trans-unit.target: To create app passwords if you do not have an Office 365 or Azure subscription

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to [https://myapps.microsoft.com](https://myapps.microsoft.com)
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to [https://myapps.microsoft.com](https://myapps.microsoft.com)

trans-unit.source: At the top, select profile.
trans-unit.target: At the top, select profile.

trans-unit.source: Click on your user name and select Additional Security Verification.
trans-unit.target: Click on your user name and select Additional Security Verification.

trans-unit.source: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords
trans-unit.target: On the proofup page, at the top, select app passwords

trans-unit.source: Click **Create**
trans-unit.target: Click **Create**

trans-unit.source: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**
trans-unit.target: Enter a name for the app password and click **Next**

trans-unit.source: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.
trans-unit.target: Copy the app password to the clipboard and paste it into your app.

trans-unit.source: Cloud
trans-unit.target: Cloud

trans-unit.source: Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers (Public Preview)
trans-unit.target: Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers (Public Preview)

trans-unit.source: Suspending Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers is a feature that allows you to give users the option to suspend MFA for a set number of days after performing a successful sign-in using MFA.
trans-unit.target: Suspending Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices and browsers is a feature that allows you to give users the option to suspend MFA for a set number of days after performing a successful sign-in using MFA.

trans-unit.source: It is a free feature for all MFA users and enhances the usability for the users.
trans-unit.target: It is a free feature for all MFA users and enhances the usability for the users.

trans-unit.source: However, since the users are allowed to suspend MFA, this feature may reduce account security.
trans-unit.target: However, since the users are allowed to suspend MFA, this feature may reduce account security.

trans-unit.source: To ensure that the user accounts are secured, you should restore Multi-Factor Authentication for their devices for either of the following scenarios:
trans-unit.target: To ensure that the user accounts are secured, you should restore Multi-Factor Authentication for their devices for either of the following scenarios:

trans-unit.source: If their corporate account has become compromised
trans-unit.target: If their corporate account has become compromised

trans-unit.source: If a remembered device is lost or stolen
trans-unit.target: If a remembered device is lost or stolen

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] This feature is implemented as a browser cookie cache.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] This feature is implemented as a browser cookie cache.

trans-unit.source: It will not work if your browser cookies are not enabled.
trans-unit.target: It will not work if your browser cookies are not enabled.

trans-unit.source: How to enable/disable Suspend MFA for remembered devices and set
trans-unit.target: How to enable/disable Suspend MFA for remembered devices and set

trans-unit.source: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign-in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: On the left, click Active Directory.
trans-unit.target: On the left, click Active Directory.

trans-unit.source: Under Active Directory, click on the directory you wish to setup Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices on.
trans-unit.target: Under Active Directory, click on the directory you wish to setup Suspend Multi-Factor Authentication for remembered devices on.

trans-unit.source: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.
trans-unit.target: On the Directory you have selected, click Configure.

trans-unit.source: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.
trans-unit.target: In the multi-factor authentication section, click Manage service settings.

trans-unit.source: On the Service Settings page, under manage user device settings, select/unselect the **Allow users to suspend multi-factor authentication by causing a device to be remembered**.
trans-unit.target: On the Service Settings page, under manage user device settings, select/unselect the **Allow users to suspend multi-factor authentication by causing a device to be remembered**.

trans-unit.source: Set the number of days that you want to allow the suspension.
trans-unit.target: Set the number of days that you want to allow the suspension.

trans-unit.source: The default is 14 days.
trans-unit.target: The default is 14 days.

trans-unit.source: Click save.
trans-unit.target: Click save.

trans-unit.source: click close.
trans-unit.target: click close.
